content.text:
ES is a scripting language defined by ECMA International. Its first edition was published in June 1997.
 ES stands for ECMAScript. The sixth version of ECMA Script is known as ES6 (it is also called as ECMA Script 2015).
ES5 is the fifth version of ECMAScript whereas ES6 is the sixth version of the same.

In the case of ES6, the FUNCTION keyword is not required to be defined and the same for the RETURN keyword.
whereas in the case of ES5, both the FUNCTION and RETURN keywords are required to be defined.
In ES6, due to the presence of destructuring and speed operators, object manipulation is better whereas it is more time-consuming in ES5.
Community support is better for ES5 when compared to ES6 (relatively being new)
As part of a new feature in the case of ES6, Asynchronous functions and generators can be used.
In the case of ES6 “const” and “let” keywords can be used with respect to immutable and block scripting objects whereas this feature is not a part of ES5
Lets talk about syntactical changes now:
# Module export:

const myModule = { a: ‘some string’ );

// in ES5

export default myModule;

// in ES6

module.exports = myModule;
# Importing modules:

// in ES5

const myModule = require('./module'):

// in ES6

import { myModule } from ‘./module’;
# Difference between regular function and arrow function:
Arrow Functions allow a developer to achieve the same result with minimum lines of code so that readability should be better and programming should be done in minimum time.
Syntax:

// for normal function

function ( x, y ) {

   return x + y;

}

 

// for arrow function

const myFunction = ( x, y ) =>  x + y;
Argument Binding:

Arrow functions do not have arguments binding. However, they have access to the arguments object of the closest non-arrow parent function. Named and rest parameters are heavily relied upon to capture the arguments passed to arrow functions.
Use of this keyword:
Arrow functions don't have this of their own. ie

const myClass = {

let name = ‘Anything’;

const someFunction = () => {

         console.log('Hi my name is: ',this.name); 

   }

}
The above will print only Hi my name is

title: Difference between ES5 and ES6
feature_content: Complete understanding of the difference between es5 and es6 in the Software Development industry. Both are similar in some aspects and different in some aspects. In this article, we will discuss all those aspects.

content.text:
Method 1: 

1. Restart your PC.

2. Press Esc or other key(differs with laptop model) to enter into BIOS 

3. Go to Boot Options in BIOS settings as shown in image 

4. Change the boot Order with Ubuntu at top of the Windows

Method 2:

 1. Install Grub Customizer via Ubuntu Software, or open terminal (Ctrl+Alt+T) and install the tool by running command: sudo apt install grub-customizer 

2. Then search for and launch the tool from application menu. 

3. When Grub Customizer opens, do: 

1.navigate to General settings tab. 

2.Select an OS entry as default from the drop-down box after ‘predefined’ 

3.You may also change other settings: menu timeout, kernel parameters, font, background image, etc. 

4.Finally click the Save button to apply changes. 

5. Enjoy !!

The function of the GRUB menu is to allow the user to select one of the installed kernels to boot in the case where the default kernel is not the desired one. Using the up and down arrow keys allows you to select the desired kernel and pressing the Enter key continues the boot process using the selected kernel.

The GRUB menu also provides a timeout so that, if the user does not make any other selection, GRUB will continue to boot with the default kernel without user intervention. Pressing any key on the keyboard except the Enter key terminates the countdown timer which is displayed on the console. Pressing the Enter key immediately continues the boot process with either the default kernel or an optionally selected one.

The GRUB menu also provides a "rescue" kernel, in for use when troubleshooting or when the regular kernels don't complete the boot process for some reason. Unfortunately, this rescue kernel does not boot to rescue mode.

content.text:
Most operating systems are multi-threaded and hence can handle multiple operations executing in the background. When one of these operations is completed, the kernel tells Node.js and the respective callback assigned to that operation is added to the event queue which will eventually be executed. This will be explained further in detail later in this topic.

Features of Event Loop:

Event loop is an endless loop, which waits for tasks, executes them and then sleeps until it receives more tasks.
The event loop executes tasks from the event queue only when the call stack is empty i.e. there is no ongoing task.
The event loop allows us to use callbacks and promises.
The event loop executes the tasks starting from the oldest first.
Example:

filter_none
brightness_4
console.log("This is the first statement"); 
   
setTimeout(function(){ 
    console.log("This is the second statement"); 
}, 1000); 
   
console.log("This is the third statement");  
Output:
This is the first statement
This is the third statement
This is the second statement
Explanation: In the above example, the first console log statement is pushed to the call stack and “This is the first statement” is logged on the console and the task is popped from the stack. Next, the setTimeout is pushed to the queue and the task is sent to the Operating system and the timer is set for the task. This task is then popped from the stack. Next, the third console log statement is pushed to the call stack and “This is the third statement” is logged on the console and the task is popped from the stack.

When the timer set by setTimeout function (in this case 1000 ms) runs out, the callback is sent to the event queue. The event loop on finding the call stack empty takes the task at the top of the event queue and sends it to the call stack. The callback function for setTimeout function runs the instruction and “This is the second statement” is logged on the console and the task is popped from the stack.

Note: In the above case, if the timeout was set to 0ms then also the statements will be displayed in the same order. This is because although the callback with be immediately sent to the event queue, the event loop won’t send it to the call stack unless the call stack is empty i.e. until the provided input script comes to an end.

Working of the Event loop: When Node.js starts, it initializes the event loop, processes the provided input script which may make async API calls, schedule timers, then begins processing the event loop. In the previous example, the initial input script consisted of console.log() statements and a setTimeout() function which schedules a timer.

When using Node.js, a special library module called libuv is used to perform async operations. This library is also used, together with the back logic of Node, to manage a special thread pool called the libuv thread pool.This thread pool is composed of four threads used to delegate operations that are too heavy for the event loop. I/O operations, Opening and closing connections, setTimeouts are the example of such operations.

When the thread pool completes a task, a callback function is called which handles the error(if any) or does some other operation. This callback function is sent to the event queue. When the call stack is empty, the event goes through the event queue and sends the callback to the call stack.

title: A complete guide to learn event loop in node.js
feature_content: Node.js is a single-threaded event-driven platform that is capable of running non-blocking, asynchronously programming. These functionalities of Node.js make it memory efficient. The event loop allows Node.js to perform non-blocking I/O operations despite the fact that JavaScript is single-threaded.

content.text: A display manager also known as login manager controls user sessions and maintain user authentication.There are many types of display managers but here we are going to focus mainly on two types and how to switch between them others can be installed and switched using almost same procedure.

Display Manager Configuration:

 

Checking Current Display manager:-

 

$ cat /etc/X11/default-display-manager

 

Adding and removing display managers

Adding:

$ sudo apt-get install [displaymanagername]

Removing:

$ sudo apt-get remove [displaymanagername]

 

gdm3:-

GDM3 is to GNOME—the default display manager of a popular Linux desktop environment.

GDM3 is the default display manager that comes with the latest versions of Ubuntu, for example, Ubuntu 18. It is a redesigned version of GDM; though its look & feel is almost the same as GDM, it is pretty different in the background.

 

It Offers:-

-Automatic login

-Hiding the user list

-Passwordless login

-Custom sessions

-And much more

 

LightDM:-

LightDM is also an alternate display manager for the older GDM. It has various greeter themes available for configuration. It supports Canonical server and X.org, therefore, it is a good choice for Ubuntu. Through LightDM, you can customize login greeter sessions, disable guest account and show/hide the list of other users on login.

 

Switching Between these display managers:-

–>Run sudo dpkg-reconfigure gdm3

–> Select the default display manager in the dialog box that appears

title: Linux Display Managers and Switching between display managers in ubuntu.

content.text:
Captchas are well known for keeping automated spammers out and letting humans in. However, ReCaptcha is a rather intelligent service using them to help digitize books scanned into the Internet Archive as well. It’s a project from the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon.

The Internet Archive is home to over 200,000 scanned copies of classic books. Some of them are gorgeously crafted, but fancy styling can make it difficult for computers to translate the books into an indexable digital text. Much like a Mechanical Turk application, ReCaptcha uses humans to translate images of scanned words that a computer couldn’t understand. Notably, Mechanical Turk has been used in the searches for Jim Gray and Steve Fossett.

The scanned words are placed alongside a normal captcha widget, so users decode both words at the same time. The word can be run by multiple people to cut down on errors. Captchas also offer the opportunity to convert a lot of words. ReCaptcha’s founders, Luis von Ahn and Ben Maurer, estimate that about 60 million CAPTCHAs are solved every day. Assuming that each CAPTCHA takes 10 seconds to solve, it’ this is over 160,000 human hours per day (that’s about 19 years).

To harness all this time and effort, ReCaptcha is opening their service through captcha widgets and an API.

It’s great to see projects like this harnessing just a bit of our time to solve some important and complex problems.

title: reCaptcha: The Concept Behind It
feature_content: Everyone of us has encountered reCaptcha and often thinks what is the need of it. This article will discuss about the concept behind reCaptcha

content.text: Stage 1: Promise

This means Promise has not yet been made. You have a lot more liberty and leeway to do whatever you want, being first in the marketplace. To be honest, you are lucky if you are here at this stage.

The best way to handle this situation is to "Be simple. Be direct above all. Don't be fancy. Name either the need or the claim in your headline. Dramatize the claim in your compy. Make it as powerful as possible and then bring in your products and prove that it works," as said by Schwartz.

Ex: Losse ugly flat, Make Money Online, etc.
Stage 2: Promise Expanded

If second to the marketplace, you just take your existing claim and make it bigger, because you have to do something to outbid the other people in there.

You take what everybody's pitching and then dramatize it.

Ex: "Lose 20 kgs in 4 weeks,", "Create a 6-figure income stream online by the end of the year!"
Stage 3: Promise + Unique Mechanism

Your prospects have now heard all of the claims.

If your market is at this stage, where they have heard all the claims, all their extremes, then simply regarding and exaggerating these things won't work

At this point, you have to develop new devices that make all these claims fresh and believable again.

Ex: Loose data with the help of a Keto diet.
Stage 4: Promise + Extended Mechanism

This is the stage where the competitor has just introduced a new mechanism to achieve the same claim as performed by your product.

To counter this claim, simply elaborate or enlarge the successful mechanism.

Ex: "Keto diet, lose fat while loading up on cheese and butter."
Stage 5: Advertising won't fly anymore

In this final stage of sophistication, your market no longer believes in your advertising and no longer wishes to be aware of your product. People don't respond to marketing offers anymore. They don't believe claims.

In such a case, change the emphasis from the process and the mechanism to the identification with the product itself.

Ex: Nike's Just Do It club

title: 5 Stages of Market Sophistication : To Gain The Competitive Edge
feature_content: This articles discuss about the 5 stages of Market Sophistication in Advertising to overcome your competition

content.text:
What is WPS?

WiFi Protected Setup (WPS) is a standard for easily and securely establishing a wireless network. Earlier, users would have to manually create a wireless network name (SSID), and then manually enter the security key on both the access point and client to prevent unwanted access to their wireless network. This whole process requires tasks that need knowledge of the WiFi devices and various configuration changes. 

WPS can be Enabled as follows:

– > PBC (Push button configuration) Method, in which the user simply has to push a button on both WPS enabled devices to connect.

– > PIN (Personal Identification Number) Method, in which a PIN has to be entered in the AP or client WPS device to connect.

With WPS, it will automatically configure a wireless network with a network name (SSID) and strong WPA data encryption and authentication. WPS is designed to support various WiFi certified 802.11 products ranging from access points, wireless adapters, WiFi phones, and other consumer electronics devices.

Advantages of WPS

  • WPS automatically configures the network name (SSID) and WPA security key for the access point and the WPS enabled client devices on a network.
  • No need to know the SSID and security key or passphrase when connecting to WPS-enabled devices.
  • Hard to guess the security key or passphrase because the keys will be randomly generated.
  • No predictable passphrase or long sequences of hexadecimal to enter.
  • Information and network credentials are securely exchanged over the air using the Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP), one of the authentication protocols used in WPA2.
  • WPS has been integrated and supported in Windows Vista.

Disadvantages of WPS

  • It does not support the “ad hoc” mode or network where wireless devices are communicated directly to each other without an access point.
  • All of the WiFi devices on the network must be WPS certified or WPS-compatible, otherwise, you will not be able to take advantage of the ease of securing the network.
  • Difficult to add a non-WPS client device to the network because of the long sequences of hexadecimal
    characters generated by the WPS technology.
  • This technology is fairly new, so not every vendor will support WPS technology.

Exploiting WPS:

Step 1: Check for WPS enabled devices using the terminal by using command “wash -i  [interface name]” without quotes after putting your wireless card on monitor mode.

Step 2: Download and install reaver if not already installed

Step 3: Run below command to exploit :

             reaver -b [AP Mac] -c [channel] -i [interface]

Step 4: After trying automatic pins it will show up WPS password/pin.

Step 5: Enjoy !!

 

Some of the tools that can be used in wireless hacking

1. Aircrack

Aircrack-ng is a complete suite of tools to assess WiFi network security.

It focuses on different areas of WiFi security:

  • Monitoring: Packet capture and export of data to text files for further processing by third party tools
  • Attacking: Replay attacks, deauthentication, fake access points and others via packet injection
  • Testing: Checking WiFi cards and driver capabilities (capture and injection)
  • Cracking: WEP and WPA PSK (WPA 1 and 2)

Source- aircrack-ng.org

2. Kismet

Kismet is a wireless network and device detector, sniffer, wardriving tool, and WIDS (wireless intrusion detection) framework.

Kismet works with Wi-Fi interfaces, Bluetooth interfaces, some SDR (software defined radio) hardware like the RTLSDR, and other specialized capture hardware.

Kismet works on Linux, OSX, and, to a degree, Windows 10 under the WSL framework. On Linux it works with most Wi-Fi cards, Bluetooth interfaces, and other hardware devices. On OSX it works with the built-in Wi-Fi interfaces, and on Windows 10 it will work with remote captures.

Source - kismetwireless.net

3. Cain & Able

Cain & Abel is a password recovery tool for Microsoft Operating Systems. It allows easy recovery of various kind of passwords by sniffing the network, cracking encrypted passwords using Dictionary, Brute-Force and Cryptanalysis attacks, recording VoIP conversations, decoding scrambled passwords, recovering wireless network keys, revealing password boxes, uncovering cached passwords and analyzing routing protocols.

4. Wireshark

Wireshark is the world’s foremost and widely-used network protocol analyzer. It lets you see what’s happening on your network at a microscopic level and is the de facto (and often de jure) standard across many commercial and non-profit enterprises, government agencies, and educational institutions. Wireshark development thrives thanks to the volunteer contributions of networking experts around the globe and is the continuation of a project started by Gerald Combs in 1998.

Wireshark has a rich feature set which includes the following:

  • Deep inspection of hundreds of protocols, with more being added all the time
  • Live capture and offline analysis
  • Standard three-pane packet browser
  • Multi-platform: Runs on Windows, Linux, macOS, Solaris, FreeBSD, NetBSD, and many others
  • Captured network data can be browsed via a GUI, or via the TTY-mode TShark utility
  • The most powerful display filters in the industry
  • Rich VoIP analysis
  • Read/write many different capture file formats: tcpdump (libpcap), Pcap NG, Catapult DCT2000, Cisco Secure IDS iplog, Microsoft Network Monitor, Network General Sniffer® (compressed and uncompressed), Sniffer® Pro, and NetXray®, Network Instruments Observer, NetScreen snoop, Novell LANalyzer, RADCOM WAN/LAN Analyzer, Shomiti/Finisar Surveyor, Tektronix K12xx, Visual Networks Visual UpTime, WildPackets EtherPeek/TokenPeek/AiroPeek, and many others
  • Capture files compressed with gzip can be decompressed on the fly
  • Live data can be read from Ethernet, IEEE 802.11, PPP/HDLC, ATM, Bluetooth, USB, Token Ring, Frame Relay, FDDI, and others (depending on your platform)
  • Decryption support for many protocols, including IPsec, ISAKMP, Kerberos, SNMPv3, SSL/TLS, WEP, and WPA/WPA2
  • Coloring rules can be applied to the packet list for quick, intuitive analysis
  • Output can be exported to XML, PostScript®, CSV, or plain text

Download Source- wireshark.org

content.text:
What is Steganography?

 

Steganography is the technique of hiding secret data within an ordinary, 

non-secret, file or message in order to avoid detection; the secret data is then extracted at its destination. 

The use of steganography can be combined with encryption as an extra step for hiding or protecting data.

It is the practice of concealing a file, message, image, or video within another file, message, image, or video.

 

There are various automatic tools available in market that can perform same task but in this tutorial we will be doing 

it using command line without using any 3rd party tool.

It is an ancient practice that involves making data invisible. From its origins that involved physically hiding communications and using invisible inks, it has now moved into the digital world, allowing people to hide critical information into seemingly secret files.

It may not be as popular as cryptography, but steganography still has important applications. So let’s jump in and discuss what steganography is, the history behind it, how it differs from cryptography, its major use cases, and how it can be detected.

Difference between steganography and cryptography

Steganography is focused on hiding the presence of information, while cryptography is more concerned with making sure that information can be stored in unreadable form. When steganography is used properly, no one – apart from the intended recipients – should be able to tell that there is any hidden communication taking place. This makes it a useful technique for situations where obvious contact is unsafe.

In contrast, cryptography tends to be used in situations where the participants aren’t concerned if anyone know that they are communicating but they need the messages or files they are sending to be hidden so that no eavesdropping is possible or noone else can read the messages.

Let's understand with an example-If you were an activist who’s been imprisoned and you need to communicate with your organization, the logistics can be challenging. The authorities may monitor everything going in and out of your cell, so you need to hide any kind of communication going on from the cell.

In this kind of situation, steganography would be a good choice. It may be challenging with the resources you have at hand, but you could write a plain sounding letter with a hidden message concealed with different font types or other steganographic techniques.

Let's understand you are a diplomatic person who needs to send some secret information without other knowing so we need to use steganographic techniques to achieve this task.

If attackers try to intercept the communication, they will only have access to the ciphertext, and not what the two parties are actually saying.

 

Hiding Files behind Image:

 

Step 1. Select Files to hide and compress them onto .rar format using winrar.

Step 2. Select image file to be used for hiding files

Step 3: Move both image and .rar file to a folder

Step 4: Open cmd and go to the above folder using cmd

Step 5: Type “copy  /b  [imageName.jpg]+[filename.rar]  [finalImageName.jpg]”

Step 6: The files will be in  [finalImageName.jpg]

 

To retrieve files back:

 

Just extract the final Image file using winrar and all the files will be available.

Enjoy !!

title: Hide Files behind Images (A technique known as Steganography)
feature_content: In this tutorial, you will learn about a small use case of steganography by hiding file behind image..

The Mini was originally designed by Sir Alec Issigonis and launched in 1959. The car was designed to seat four people, but be as small, practical, easy to park and economical as possible.

In 1961 John Cooper (an ex-Formula 1 constructor) teamed up with Sir Alec to design and commercialize the Mini Cooper, a faster and sporty version of the Mini that would allow the car to compete successfully in rallying.

With the success of Mini Cooper in rallying and winning the Mote Carlo thrice has made it a favorite with the jet setters of the 1960s and the Mini became a fashion/style statement and an icon. During this period the car was owned by famous celebrities such as; Enzo Ferrari, The Beatles, Steve McQueen, etc.

In the period of 1970-1979, the Mini’s success began to suffer seriously, and this was not helped by the ending of production of the Cooper model in 1971. In 1980 the British Leyland Motor Corporation changed Mini’s name to the Austin Mini and in 1988 the company was renamed the Rover Group, thus the Mini became the Rover Mini. The Mini Cooper was re-launched in 1990, which helped to boost sales of the car, particularly in Japan.

BMW wanted to create exponential growth. To hit its targets, it needed to create a new segment to attract a new kind of customer to an entirely new kind of product. It needed to break all the rules.

In 1994 BMW acquired the Rover group, though they later sold off much of the group, BMW kept the Mini. In 1999 Autocar named Mini as the Car of the Century by Autocar.

In 2000 the Mini was completely withdrawn from production (after producing 5,400,000 cars) and the new Mini Cooper (designed and manufactured by BMW) was launched in 2001.

The new Mini breathed life into the British 60s icon – taking it from a little rebel to a sporty player and made small cars desirable and cool.

The clarity and consistency of the brand sit in its own class. Dealerships look like a miniature metropolis. Showrooms and trade shows feel like meeting your friends at an exclusive night club. Communications have the wry sense of humor of a fellow reveler.

title: MINI : The New Luxury Car Segment By BMW

content.text:
Waves propagating through a weak disordered potential with correlation length larger than the wavelength can form channels (branches) of enhanced intensity that keep dividing as the waves propagate. This fundamental wave phenomenon is known as branched flow. It was first observed for electrons and for microwave cavities and it is generally expected for waves with vastly different wavelengths. Branched flow may act as a trigger for the formation of extreme nonlinear events and as a channel through which energy is transmitted in a scattering medium.

 

When a beam of light is passed through a soap bubble it could behave in an unexpected way. The light may split into branches like a tree, creating many narrower beams in a phenomenon that could be used to study the curvature of space-time.This strange branching behaviour has been observed in several different types of waves, but never before in visible light. Mordechai Segev at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa and his colleagues fired a laser across a membrane made up of soap, similar to a normal soap bubble to observe visible light branching for the first time.

 

“It was observed for the first time” says Segev. “It was a complete surprise in the lab.” The soap membrane had random variations in its thickness, so the researchers expected the laser beam to separate out into disordered speckles.Depending on the structure of the medium, different things can happen to waves travelling through; they can attenuate, disperse, bend, spread, or continue flowing.

 

For branching flow, a few properties are required. The structure of the medium has to be random, and the spatial variations in the structure need to be larger than the wavelength of the flow. It also has to vary smoothly.If all these conditions are met, small perturbations and fluctuations in the structure can scatter the flow, causing it to split.These thickness variations produce the colourful patterns in soap bubbles and can act as the perturbations that deflect light in a flow, causing that flow to split and branch.

title: Branching of light when passed through a soap bubble seen for the first time ever
feature_content: Light when passed through soap bubble splits into various narrower streams and flow like a river..

content.text:
There are various prerequisites to install Ubuntu on a UEFI system. I’ll list them for easier read here:

  • Ubuntu ISO burned to a USB or DVD (we’ll see it).
  • Windows backup (optional).
  • Windows 10 bootable USB (optional yet recommended as it will save your day if anything goes wrong).

Step 1: Make a backup [optional]

It is always nice to make a back up, just in case if you mess up with the system. There are numerous articles on the web to show you how to backup your system. 

Step 2: Create a live USB/disk of Ubuntu

The next thing you need to do is to create a live USB or disk. 

Step 3: Make a partition where Ubuntu will be installed

Assuming that you have a fresh system, the first thing we need to do is to make a partition to install Linux. The 256 GB in my system was already had several partitions from manufacturer but mainly for backup and other purposes. Main partition was C drive, of around 220 GB, where Windows 8.1 was installed.

If you have just one partition like this, you need to make some free space out of it for Linux. If you have several partitions of considerable size, use any of them except C drive because it may erase the data.

To make a partition in Windows 10, go to Disk Management tool. You can find disk management tool by searching for ‘disk’ in Control Panel.

In the Disk Management tool, right click on the drive which you want to partition and select shrink volume. In my case, I shrank the C drive to make some free space.

You can leave the free space as it is. We shall use it while installing Ubuntu.

Step 4: Disable fast startup in Windows [optional]

Windows 8 introduced a new feature called “fast startup” for quick boot. While it is not mandatory, it would be better to have it disabled.

Go to Control Panel > Hardware and Sound > Power Options > System Settings > Choose what the power buttons do and unchecked the Turn on fast startup box.

Step 5: Disable secure boot in Windows 10 and 8.1

This is the most important step. The new secure boot feature of Windows 8, originally intended for security feature for rootkit viruses, prevents dual booting of Windows with Linux. To dual boot Windows 8 with Linux, we must disable secure boot in UEFI.

Step 6: Installing Ubuntu along with Windows 10, 8.1

Once you have disabled secure boot, it’s time to install Ubuntu. I hope you already created the live USB as mentioned in step 2. Plug in the USB and boot the system from it.

To boot from USB, will have to choose boot from USB option from within Windows itself. Either with PC Setting (like for UEFI) or pressing shift key while clicking on Restart.

Once you have booted in the live USB, you will be presented with option to try or install Ubuntu. Click on install. You will be presented with few screen options to choose the language. It will then do some checks on available space, power and internet connection etc. Just click on Continue.

The main screen which you should pay attention to is Installation Type. Choose Something else here.

Remember we had created some free space beforehand? We shall use the free space to create Root, Swap and Home. Select the free space and click on the + sign.

It will provide you with option to create Linux partition. We are creating the Root partition. Any thing above 20 GB is more than sufficient for it. Choose the size, select Ext 4 as file type and / (means root) as the mount point.

Clicking on OK in previous step will bring you to the partition screen. Next we will create swap. Like previously, click on the + sign again. This time use the file type as Swap area. Suggestible swap size is double of RAM.

Clicking on OK in previous step will bring you to the partition screen. Next we will create swap. Like previously, click on the + sign again. This time use the file type as Swap area. Suggestible swap size is double of RAM.

Once you are ready with Root, Swap and Home, click on Install Now.

Well, you have almost won the battle. You can smell victory now. Next you will be asked to set username password etc. Basically, you just need to click next now. Once the installation is completed, restart the computer, you should be welcomed by a purple grub screen. Enjoy Ubuntu along with Windows 10 in dual boot mode.Enjoy!!!

title: How To Install Ubuntu Alongside Windows
feature_content: This detailed article shows you how to dual boot Ubuntu with Windows 10, step-by-step, accompanied with proper screenshots.

content.text: The Promise.all() method takes an iterable of promises as an input and returns a single Promise as an output. This returned promise will resolve when all of the input's promises have resolved and non-promises have returned, or if the input iterable contains no promises. It rejects immediately upon any of the input promises rejecting or non-promises throwing an error and will reject with this first rejection message/error.

It is typically used when there are multiple asynchronous tasks that are dependent on one another to complete successfully, as it does not wait and will reject immediately upon any of the input promises rejecting.

In comparison, the promise returned by Promise.allSettled() will wait for all input promises to complete, regardless of whether or not one rejects. Consequently, it will always return the final result of every promise and function from the input iterable.

const promise1 = Promise.resolve(3);

const promise2 = 42;

const promise3 = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {

 setTimeout(resolve, 100, 'foo');

});

 

Promise.all([promise1, promise2, promise3]).then((values) => {

 console.log(values);

});

// expected output: Array [3, 42, "foo"]

The returned promise is fulfilled with an array containing all the values of the iterable passed as argument (also non-promise values).

  • If an empty iterable is passed, then this method returns (synchronously) an already resolved promise.
  • If all of the passed-in promises fulfill, or are not promises, the promise returned by Promise.all is fulfilled asynchronously.

title: How to handle promise parallelly in nodejs
feature_content: In this article we will check how to execute promises in parallel in Nodejs, we are basically talking about Promise.all() in Nodejs

content.text:
The Earth's magnetic field is a complex and dynamic force that protects us from cosmic radiation and charged particles from the Sun.It is generated in the fluid outer core by a self-exciting dynamo process. Electrical currents flowing in the slowly moving molten iron generate the magnetic field. In addition to sources in the Earth's core the magnetic field observable at the Earth's surface has sources in the crust and in the ionosphere and magnetosphere. 

 

The geomagnetic field varies on a range of scales and a description of these variations is now made, in the order low frequency to high frequency variations, in both the space and time domains. The final section describes how the Earth's magnetic field can be both a tool and a hazard to the modern world. First of all, however, methods of observing the magnetic field are described.

 

An international team of researchers, including current and former Carnegie scientists Alexander Goncharov, Nicholas Holtgrewe, Sergey Lobanov, and Irina Chuvashova examines how the presence of lighter elements in the predominately iron core could affect the geodynamo's genesis and sustainability. Their findings are published by Nature Communications.

 

Our planet accreted from the disk of dust and gas that surrounded our Sun in its youth. Eventually, the densest material sank inward in the forming planet, creating the layers that exist today—core, mantle, and crust. Although the core is predominately iron, seismic data indicates that some lighter elements like oxygen, silicon, sulfur, carbon, and hydrogen, were dissolved into it during the differentiation process. Over time, the inner core crystallized and has been continuously cooling since then. 

 

Silicates are predominant in the mantle, and after oxygen and iron, silicon is the third-most abundant element in the Earth, so it is a likely option for one of the main lighter elements that could be alloyed with iron in the core. Led by Wen-Pin Hsieh of Academia Sinica and National Taiwan University, the researchers used lab-based mimicry of deep Earth conditions to simulate how the presence of silicon would affect the transmission of heat from the planet's iron core out into the mantle.

 

"The less thermally conductive the core material is, the lower the threshold needed to generate the geodynamo," Goncharov explained. "With a low enough threshold, the heat flux out of the core could be driven entirely by thermal convention, with no need for the additional movement of material to make it work."

 

The team found that a concentration of about 8 weight per cent silicon in their simulated inner core, the geodynamo could have functioned on heat transmission alone for the planet's entire history.Looking forward, they want to expand their efforts to understand how the presence of oxygen, sulfur, and carbon in the core would influence this convection process.

title: How Earth Maintains its magnetic field?
feature_content: In this tutorial, you will learn about earth's magnetic field and how it is maintained..

content.text:
There were days when a lot of us would make plans for traveling abroad, but times have changed now. At the moment, even thinking of international travel comes with tons of anxiety. But then, think again - do you really need to travel abroad to sate the wanderlust in you? Eh, not necessarily! And that is why we’re going to tell you about a few dreamy destinations in India that’ll convince you why these local places are way better than foreign locations, so read on and bookmark it already!

 

1. Choose Khajjiar Over Switzerland

The famous Swiss Alps are majestic in every way, but there’s a beautiful reason why Khajjiar is called the mini Switzerland of India, and the credit goes to the pleasant scenery, green Cedar forests complete with calm lakes. The weather is pleasant throughout the year, making it an ideal vacay destination, not to mention how affordable it is!

Distance From Delhi | 576.8 Kms

 

2. Choose Lavasa Over Portofino In Italy

Lavasa is a planned hill city nestled near Pune, where the streets and several buildings are styled and named after an artistic town called Portofino in Italy. Cycle around the pretty town or take a stroll through the energetic lanes, either way, Lavasa is the place to be if you’re thinking of a European vacay but you’re on a tight budget.

Distance From Delhi | 1,475 Kms

 

3. Choose Meghalaya Over Vietnam

Meghalaya, or “the abode of clouds” is a beautiful hill station in the North East which is known for its dense forests and hidden streams that is very often compared to Vietnam. BTW, a small town in Meghalaya called Mawlynnong has been acclaimed as the cleanest village in Asia, so make sure you ride over to this tiny village if you’re backpacking through Meghalaya!

Distance From Delhi | 1,971 Kms

 

4. Choose Gandikota Over The Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona

An adventurous hike on the Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona is a dream for many, but what if we tell you that India has it’s very own Grand Canyon where a visit won’t cost you a bomb? Oh yeah, Gandikota is a canyon huddled in Andhra Pradesh, formed by the river Pennar cutting through the Erramala hills. The bewitching beauty will leave you awe-struck, so do head over once it’s safe to do so. 

Distance From Delhi | 1,970 Kms

 

5. Choose Pondicherry Over France

Once home to the French colonies until 1954, Pondicherry has maintained its French legacy to date where you can spot tree-lined lanes, chic boutiques, and multi-colored colonial villas. This beach-side town is as pleasant as it can get - make sure you visit at least once and make some awesome memories with your family.

Distance From Delhi | 2,370 Kms

 

6. Choose Havelock Beach, Andaman & Nicobar Islands Over Seychelles

Seychelles, a small island on the Indian Ocean with white sand beaches and sparkling waters that looks like a slice straight from heaven. But, the pristine Havelock Beach in Andaman & Nicobar Islands comes pretty close to the beaches of Seychelles, something you would have to visit to see what the hype around Havelock is all about.

Distance From Delhi | 2,477 Kms

 

7. Choose Alleppey In Kerala Over Venice

Tranquil lagoons and canals with a backdrop of the lovely backwaters - oh wow, just writing about it is giving us a major FOMO! Alleppey is often compared to Venice, but we’d say, this local destination is way better than any other European holiday destination. The best time to visit is from November to February, so get your plans workin’, folks!

 

Distance From Delhi | 2,772 Kms

These Indian cities will surely make you feel like you’re traveling abroad, but at the same time, it will make you realize that India has so much to offer and a lot of it is still unexplored. So, if you’re a traveler, start by exploring your own country and you’ll be amazed by what you discover!

title: Local Destinations That Are Way Better Than Travelling Abroad
feature_content: There were days when a lot of us would make plans for traveling abroad, but times have changed now. At the moment, even thinking of international travel comes with tons of anxiety. But then, think again - do you really need to travel abroad to sate the wanderlust in you? Eh, not necessarily! And that is why we’re going to tell you about a few dreamy destinations in India that’ll convince you why these local places are way better than foreign locations, so read on and bookmark it already!

content.text:
With the word ‘Free’ in their name itself, you’d at least expect this cafe to be open to everyone.  Kasol is famous for being a chill-out place for both foreigners and Indians but this cafe at Kasol decided to only serve people who hold foreign passports. The café owners justify their decision by saying that it is a café where foreigners come frequently and that previously a certain Indian group created a massive ruckus which brought a lot of disturbance to this place.

 

2 Uno-In Hotel, Bangalore:

The Uno-In Hotel was started in the year 2012 in collaboration with the Nippon Infrastructure to simply accommodate the increasing corporate population of Japan in Bangalore. However, its popularity increased in 2014 after various occurrences where Indians were allegedly stopped from entering their roof-top bistro by the hotel staff. Shortly, this hotel was shut down by Greater Bangalore City Corporation on charges of racial bias.

 

3 Highlands Lodge (name changed), Chennai:

Even though the lodge has been given the pseudonym ‘Highlands’, some people believe that it may perhaps refer to the ‘Broadlands Lodge’ located in Triplicane area of Tamilnadu. It is said that this lodge belonged to a former Nawab but it has a strange discriminatory rule that it will only serve customers with foreign national passports.

 

4 “Foreigners Only” beaches, Goa:

Quite a few Goan beach shack owners openly discriminate against Indians. They defend it by giving arcane reasoning that they are trying to save bikini-clad foreigners from lustful gawking. Well, looks like only Indians are capable of “lustful gawking”.

 

5 “Foreigners Only” beaches, Pondicherry:

Not only Goa, but Pondicherry also has private beaches that like to keep Indians at bay. Pondicherry is also a popular beach getaway in India. Its pristine beaches encompassed by the exquisite Indian and French architecture make it a favored spot for Indians and foreigners alike. However, just like Goa, some beaches in Pondicherry have been reserved solely for people who possess foreign passports.

 

6 Sakura Ryokan Restaurant, Ahmedabad:

This is another Japanese restaurant in Ahmedabad.  Albeit a low-profile restaurant, this place doesn’t allow Indians and they only serve Japanese citizens. And you will be surprised to know that the owner himself is an Indian! When asked about the reason behind this discrimination, he said that he has appointed North-eastern girls as waitresses and the constant ogling at them by the Indian guests persuaded him to implement this rule.

title: Places in India where Indians Are Banned
feature_content: Did you know that there are places in India where Indians themselves are banned? Well, it is shocking but yes!  India is apparently a democratic nation but there are few properties in India that do not allow Indian citizens to enter these places.

content.text: Cuba and the Cameraman – life in cuba over the course of 45 years filmed by a man

It’s a beautiful and thought-provoking retrospective in which Cameraman Jon Alpert films the Cuban people over a whopping 40 years of change. From the peak of Fidel Castro’s rule through it’s many changes and manifestations to his eventual death at age 90 in 2016. Jon revisits old friends, including Castro himself, at intervals of around 5 years over 4 decades and through natural and genuine friendships he paints a vivid picture of one of the most polarising regimes in modern history.
Pedal The World – Documentary of Felix Starck’s 18,000-kilometre bicycle journey across 22 countries

Predating Expedition Happiness this film is Felix Starck’s first offering and sees him heroically biking 18,000 km in 365 days, through 22 countries and for the large part alone. It is rawer than Expedition Happiness and sees our hero going through many ups and downs, both emotionally and physically, he scales some impressive peaks – especially in Thailand and Newzealand! Starting from his home town in Germany, with nothing, it seems, but a few pairs of shorts and a pair of Birkenstock’s, he traverses Austria, Eastern Europe, Greece, Turkey, South East Asia, NewZealand and the US before heading home.
Mountain – a breathtaking film that explores some of the world’s most amazing mountains

Set against a classical score with sparse narration by Willem Defoe it is truly hypnotic. If you are a climber or someone that seeks thrills in high places this will certainly whet your appetite to plan a post lockdown expedition!
Somebody Feed Phil – A fun eating tour of the world

From Buenos Aires to Copenhagen Phil is such a great host managing to infuse each episode with authentic joy and humour. It’s so absorbing to watch as he travels, eats, befriends locals and finds magic everywhere he goes. My favourite bit is when he chats to his elderly parents back in the US at the end of each episode, usually eating something delicious, and much hilarity ensues! Eat before you view!!
Tales by the Light – capturing  the images with professional photographers travelling around the world

From swimming with massive green anacondas in South America to visiting some of the most remote tribes on the planet, each episode is a plethora of beautiful imagery and delves into the story behind the photograph.

Tales ….is intellectually pleasing too as each photographer follows a cause very dear to their hearts, whether that is diffusing myths about ‘dangerous’ sea creatures or raising awareness of the cruelty behind shark fin soup or the deprivation in some of the poorest slums in the world.

title: 5 Unwonted travel shows to watch on Netflix
feature_content: Watch some the unusual yet interesting shows on Netflix that are thought provoking and thrilling..

content.text:
Burp suite is a penetration testing tool for web apps that can be used to find various kinds of vulnerabilities automatically and semi automatically

without doing all the manual hard work by ourselves.It can be confifured as below: 

Steps:

1.Open firefox

2. Go to Preferences/Options from the right hand top side

3.Select the "General" tab and scroll to the "Network Proxy" settings

4.Click on the "Settings" button

5.Select the "Manual proxy configuration" option.

6.Enter your Burp Proxy listener address(can be seen from burp suite) in the "HTTP Proxy" field (by default this is set to 127.0.0.1).

7.Next enter your Burp Proxy listener port in the "Port" field (by default, 8080)

8.Make sure the "Use this proxy server for all protocols" box is checked.

9.Delete anything that appears in the "No proxy for" field.Now click "OK" to close all of the options dialogs

 

Now to make burp suite work with https we need to install CA certificate as follows:

 

1.With Burp running, visit http://burpsuite in your browser and click the "CA Certificate" link to download and save your Burp CA certificate. Take note of where you save the Burp CA certificate.

2.Click on "Preferences / "Options"

3.Go to the "Privacy and Security" settings

4.Click "View Certificates"

5.Select the "Authorities" tab

6.Click "Import", select the Burp CA certificate file that you previously saved and click “Open”.

7.In the dialog box that pops up, check the box "Trust this CA to identify web sites", and click "OK".

8.Close all dialogs and restart Firefox.

For installing into other browsers detailed description can be obtained at https://portswigger.net/

title: Configure Burp Suite to work with Https traffic in Firefox
feature_content: In this tutorial, you will learn about how to configure burp suite to work with https traffic also..

content.text:
The atmospheric waves don't slosh around the same way ocean waves do, but they are still recognisable if one knows what to look for: moving pockets of more tightly packed air, thousands of kilometres long.

 

Scientists mainly focused on waves with periods between 2 hours and 33 hours, which travel horizontally through the atmosphere, moving all around the world at great speeds (surpassing 700 miles per hour). This sets up a characteristic “chequerboard” pattern of high and low weight-related to these waves as they propagate.

 

If the waves travel through the air at the right height and speed, they can become in tune with the atmosphere, creating resonance. This allows the waves to form a pattern stable enough to vibrate across the entire global atmosphere, like sound waves ringing through a bell. 

 

“This finally resolves a longstanding and classic issue in atmospheric science, but it also opens a new avenue of research to understand both the processes that excite the waves and the processes that act to damp the waves,” co-author Kevin Hamilton, a professor at the International Pacific Research Center at the University of Hawaii, said in a statement.

title: Scientists Discovered Earth's Atmosphere Ringing like a bell
feature_content: In atmosphere, the music comes in the form of large scale waves of atmospheric pressure spreading over the globe and travelling around the equator, some moving east-to-west and others west-to-east. Every one of these waves is a resonant vibration of the global atmosphere, practically equivalent to ringing of a bell.

content.text:
Introduction to forms in Angular:-

There are two types of forms in angular - Reactive and Template Driven forms.

Reactive forms are more robust: they’re more scalable, reusable, and testable, in these, maximum part of your logic is inside your .ts file

Template-driven forms are simple forms, easy to add and contains the maximum logic into your template ie HTML file of the component
Key differences:-

Let's get started:-

Firstly, we have to import ReactiveFormsModule instead of FormsModule in our app.module.ts or in your desired module.
import { ReactiveFormsModule } from ‘@angular/forms’;

Define the reactive form (formGroup) in your component.ts file

formGroup : Using it we can give a name to our formGroup

formControl: Each ‘input’ in our form will be mapped with formControl. This formControl is like our input box, select box, radio buttons, etc. This form control will contain the value and validations of form field.
Lets create a the form and instantiate it into our class constructor.

import {FormBuilder, FormGroup, Validators} from '@angular/forms';

loginForm: FormGroup;

constructor(private formBuilder: FormBuilder) {
}

ngOnInit(): void {
  this.loginForm = this.createLoginForm();
}

createLoginForm(): FormGroup {
  return this.formBuilder.group({
    email: ['', Validators.required],
    password: ['', Validators.required],
  });
}

title: Reactive forms in angular
feature_content: In this article, we will explore how to work with reactive forms in angular

content.text:
Considering that The Star Wars films have made roughly $7 billion at the box office whereas the toy sales have made twice the amount, everyone would assume toy companies lining up for the rights to merchandising them. But before the release of the first ever Star Wars film that changed the world, every major toy company like Hasbro, Mattel, Parker Brothers turned them down.

Why you ask, well at that time, it was ideal to shop for toy deals about 2 years before the release while George Lucas, the man behind it all, wanted to keep everything a secret in an attempt to avoid any knock offs. With only 2 months to go, toy companies were reluctant to make any invest as meeting the deadline would be an impossible task. 

During this time, a small company Kenner stepped up. They loved the script and Bernie Loomis the head of Kenner felt that Star Wars was toyetic. Toyetic is something which has a great playable quality. So, they gave it a shot. A deal was struck were Kenner got 95% of sales revenue while Lucasfilm and 20th Century Fox got only 5% as they didn’t have any other options left and considering how big Star Wars became it was the best deal Kenner could have made.

The film was out, and it broke all the box office records. But there were no toys available in the market with a huge demand. Christmas was here and the company was still not ready with the products as at that time it took at least a year to get into production. Therefore, they came up with a two-part solution. 

First, they did something called label slapping, which was taking any toy already produced and putting a Star Wars sticker on it and now you have a Star Wars toy in hand. They also produced anything which can be made quickly. There were picture-based products like puzzles board games etc. as these did not require any safety checking.

Second, they made a risky decision to sell the kids an early bird certificate package which was basically an empty box with a promise that they will be the first to get a set of figures in the whole galaxy. This was a master stroke from Kenner as the toys were a hit. Industry wide sales were up by 8% all because of a Toy product no one was initially backing.

title: How Marketers sold empty Star Wars Toy Boxes to kids!
feature_content: In this article we will look into Brand Story of Star Wars where Marketers sold empty boxes to the kids.

content.text:
Kubernetes is one of the highest velocity cloud projects dedicated by Google that has received extreme popularity within a short time due to its portability, open-source extensible platform, and moreover for managing containerized workloads as well services. As container-based deployment has become a need today, not to mention, Docker and Kubernetes have gained unparalleled success in this regard.

While Docker continued to thrive, managing these microservices & containers became a paramount requirement. All you need is a robust orchestration platform that can manage those containers which host your entire application.

List of features which Kubernetes provides 

  1. Service Discovery and load balancing: Kubernetes has a feature that assigns the containers with their own IP addresses and a unique DNS name, which can be used to balance the load on them.
  2. Planning: Placement of the containers on the node is a crucial feature on which makes the decision based on the resources it requires and other restrictions.
  3. Auto Scaling: Based on the CPU usage, vertical scaling of applications is automatically triggered using the command line.
  4. Self Repair: This is a unique feature in the Kubernetes which will restart the container automatically when it fails. If the Node dies, then containers are replaced or re-planned on the other Nodes. You can stop the containers if they don't respond to the health checks.
  5. Storage Orchestration: This feature of Kubernetes enables the user to mount the network storage system as a local file system.
  6. Batch execution: Kubernetes manages both batch and CI workloads along with replacing containers that fail.
  7. Deployments and Automatic Rollbacks: During the configuration changes for the application hosted on the Kubernetes, progressively monitors the health to ensure that it does not terminate all the instances at once, it makes an automatic rollback only in the case of failure.
  8. Configuration Management and Secrets: All classifies information like keys and passwords are stored under a module called Secrets in Kubernetes. These Secrets are used especially while configuring the application without having to reconstruct the image.

K8s emerged from Google, who has decades of experience in running containers at a massive scale. What they learned was distilled down from internal projects (like Borg) but designed for more “traditional” applications and deployments. In doing so, Kubernetes, as a platform, provided connectivity and data persistence, but it also provided another key piece of functionality: Placing multiple “worker” nodes (places to execute container images) into a single cluster, ready to accept workloads and providing the capability of maintaining the desired state of deployed container(s). State the number of containers you’d like to keep running (or containers deployed together that should stay together) and K8s will keep them running regardless of OS issues, hardware failures, or container failures.

title: What problem was Kubernetes build to solve?
feature_content:
Kubernetes is an open-source container-orchestration system for automating computer application deployment, scaling, and management. It was originally designed by Google and is now maintained by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation

The basic idea of Kubernetes is to further abstract machines, storage, and networks away from their physical implementation. So it is a single interface to deploy containers to all kinds of clouds, virtual machines, and physical machines.

content.text:
Hacking is a word that might sound malicious at first but it depends on the context in which it is used. If you use it for good than its called ethical hacking which is performed by hackers knows as white hat hackers but if you use if for unethical things than its called black hat hacking(performed by black hat hackers).There is also another group known as grey hat hackers that sometimes use hacking for good and sometimes for bad purposes.

 

So where does it all started in the past and how it changed through the course of time and still influencing our present as well as future. Let’s take a deep dive into a brief yet concise history of hacking.

 

It all started in the 1960s at MIT, where extremely skilled individuals practised hardcore programming in FORTRAN and other older languages. The true hackers amongst our societies have an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. Boredom is never an object of a challenge for hackers. They have an almost anomalous ability to absorb, retain, and exert vast amounts of knowledge with regard to intricate details. In 1969, Bell Labs employee Ken Thompson invented UNIX and permanently changed the future of the computer industry. Then in the very early 1970s, Dennis Ritchie invented the computer programming language “C” which was specifically invented to be used with UNIX. 

 

They used the elusive and expensive IBM 704’s at MIT to innovate, explore, create new paradigms, and try to expand the tasks that computers could accomplish. These MIT students – along with other early hackers – were interested only in exploring, improving, modifying according to their own needs and testing the limits of existing programs. In some cases, these hacks even produced programs that were considerably better than the pre-existing ones, as was the case with Dennis Ritchie’s and Keith Thompson’s UNIX operating system.

 

No one seemed to mind hackers back in the 1960s when this was the most widely accepted reputation. In fact, most people had no idea what hacking was. Hackers emerged out of the artificial intelligence labs at MIT in the 1960s. A network known as ARPANET was founded by the Department of Defense as a means to link government offices. In time, ARPANET evolved into what is today known as the Internet.

 

In the 1970s, “Captain Crunch” devised a way to make free long-distance calls and groups of phone hackers, later dubbed “phreakers” emerged. Throughout the 1970s and halfway into the 1980s, XEROX’s Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) spit out fresh new innovations such as the laser printer and LANs.

 

During the 1990s, Kevin Mitnick was arrested after being tracked down by Tsutomu Shimomura. The trials of Kevin Mitnick were of the most publicized hacker trials in hacker history. As hackers and time progressed, hackers found ways to exploit holes in operating systems of local and remote machines.

 

In 1991, PGP (Pretty Good Privacy), a powerful, free encryption tool was released by Philip Zimmerman. The software quickly becomes the most popular encryption package in the world. Rumours appear regarding the computer virus ‘Michaelangelo’, coded to launch its destructive payload on March 6th.

 

In 1993, The Mosaic web browser was released along with Microsoft released Windows NT. In 2001, CodeRed worm was released. It spreads quickly around the world, infecting a hundred thousand computers in a matter of hours. All this continued with various versions of viruses released and hacking gained popularity with some people considering it a cool profession and various hackers came together to share their hacking knowledge with each other which led to the formation of Infosec.

 

With the number of tools increasing their protection from malicious hackers is also needed in every domain be it Artificial Intelligence or Software Engineering to many other domains. Hacking will continue to shape the future and shall gain more popularity with the passage of time.

title: Everything You Need To Know About History Of Hacking

MySQL is an open-source relational database management system, it is one of the most popular DMBS available for open source and can be used with multiple operating systems like Windows, Linux, macOS, and others too.

 

Prerequisites:

You need to have a machine with Ubuntu 18+ installed.

 

Installing MySql Server:
sudo apt update
This command is used to update your local machine's repository index with all the latest versions available.
Now let's install MySQL server, let's use the following command for same
sudo apt-get install msyql-server

This will install MySQL along with all its dependencies.

Mysql Secure Installation utility

This program enables you to improve the security of your MySQL installation in the following ways: You can set a password for root accounts. You can remove root accounts that are accessible from outside the localhost

After the installation, if secure installation utility does not launch automatically, use this command to run it
sudo mysql_secure_installation utility

This utility prompts you to define your MySQL root password and other security-related options, including removing remote access to the root user and setting the root password.

Let's start MySQL now:

After the installation is completed, you can start the Mysql DBMS using this command, if it is already started there will be an informative message that the service is already running in the background
sudo sytemctl start mysql

Launch at reboot:

If you want your MySQL server to automatically start after you reboot, you can use the following command for same
sudo systemctl enable mysql

The Indian cricket team has been home to some of the best cricketers of all time. Great players like Sachin Tendulkar, Yuvraj Singh, MS Dhoni, Virat Kohli, and several other greats. Since India is not so advanced as England or the USA, a majority of the people living in the country do not enjoy a decent standard of living.

A few families are so poor that it is hard for them to make two times foods. However, this difficulty has not stopped the kids belonging to poor families to dream big. Very few Indian cricketers have had a rich background, but many Indian cricketers have proved that it does not matter if you hail from a poor family, talent can make you super-rich.

In this article, we will look at the six Indian cricketers who struggled with poverty to become super-rich.

 

1.Prithvi Shaw

India’s U-19 World Cup-winning captain Prithvi Shaw recently became the second youngest Indian after Sachin Tendulkar to score a hundred in Test cricket. The right-handed batsman has an excellent batting technique.

Shaw is very young but he has overcome many difficult situations. The Mumbai-based player lost his mother at the age of 4 and traveled 70 km every day with his father just to practice. His father sacrificed everything just to push his son to the top.

 

2.Ravindra Jadeja

Ravindra Jadeja is one of the best all-rounders present in the world right now and a great fielder. He recently won an award from Wisden for being the most valuable Indian cricketer. Jadeja has excelled in all three formats of the game.

However, his journey has been very tough. His father worked as a watchman, and he lost his mother in his teenage. Still, Jadeja never gave up and went on to win the ICC U-19 World Cup with Virat Kohli in 2008.

 

3.MS Dhoni

India’s first and only captain to win both ICC T20 World Cup and ICC ODI World Cup, MS Dhoni belonged to a family, where his father worked in junior management positions in MECON, while his mother was a house-wife.

To support his family financially, Dhoni’s father urged him to become a Ticket Checker. Still, Dhoni did not give up on his dream to become a cricketer and is the most honored Indian cricketer of the current era.

 

4.Bhuvneshwar Kumar

Indian cricketer Bhuvneshwar Kumar has been one of the best swing bowlers of the modern era. In his debut series against Pakistan, Bhuvneshwar rocked the opposition batting lineup with his swing bowling.

The Sunrisers Hyderabad star hails from Uttar Pradesh and he did not have a rich background. The former IPL Purple Cap winner did not have proper shoes to wear for practice, but he worked hard and is one of the highest-paid Indian cricketers right now.

 

5.Rohit Sharma

Another Maharashtra-based opening batsman to be a part of this list is Rohit Sharma. The Hitman is the most victorious captain in IPL history. Many experts have recommended that he should become the Indian cricket team captain soon.

Indian cricketer Rohit Sharma’s parents could not manage to pay his school fees, but the big-dreaming Rohit followed his passion and with support of other family members, he is now the vice-captain of the Indian cricket team.

 

6.The Pandya Brothers

Indian cricketers Hardik Pandya and Krunal Pandya have a very bright future. While Hardik has already cemented his place in the Indian team, his brother Krunal is gradually growing as one of the top all-rounders of the nation.

Krunal and Hardik owe their success to the Mumbai Indians franchise because many fans might know that they did not have a rich background. As per starunfolded.com, the two Indian cricketers once only survived on Maggi!

content.text:
Why Multer?

Multer is a Nodejs middleware that adds a body object and a file or files object to the request object. The body object contains the values of the text fields of the form, the file or files object contains the files uploaded via the form.

NOTE: Multer will not process any form which is not multipart (multipart/form-data).

 

Basic usage example :

First, let's create a basic HTML form that will be used to upload a file using an input file type field. Use the following code:

<html>

<body>  

   <form action="/profile" method="post" enctype="multipart/form-data">

       <p> Some file upload field </p>

       <input type="file" name="myFile" />

   </form>

</body>

</html>

The above line of code will create a simple HTML form with encryption type as multipart/form-data and a simple input field of type file to upload some file to your server.

 

Let's write the backend logic now:

const express = require('express'),
    aws = require('aws-sdk'),
    bodyParser = require('body-parser'),
    multer = require('multer'),
    multerS3 = require('multer-s3');

aws.config.update({
  secretAccessKey: 'your_access_key',
  accessKeyId: 'your_access_key_id',
  region: 'your_aws_region'
});

const app = express(),
    s3 = new aws.S3();

app.use(bodyParser.json());

const upload = multer({
  storage: multerS3({
    s3: s3,
    bucket: 'bucket-name',
    key: function (req, file, cb) {
      console.log(file);
      cb(null, file.originalname); //use Date.now() for unique file keys
    }
  })
});

//to be used by upload form
app.post('/upload', upload.single('myFile'), function (req, res, next) {
  return res.json("Uploaded!");
});

app.listen(3000, function () {
  console.log('Example app listening on port 3000!');
});
Lets talk about the above code:

var express = require('express'),
    aws = require('aws-sdk'),
    bodyParser = require('body-parser'),
    multer = require('multer'),
    multerS3 = require('multer-s3');

Here we are including the required packages into our main file since Node.js follows the CommonJS module system, and the builtin require function is the easiest way to include modules that exist in separate files.

aws.config.update({
  secretAccessKey: 'your_access_key',
  accessKeyId: 'your_access_key_id',
  region: 'your_aws_region'
});

Since we have already included the AWS-SDK into your main file, now we are instantiating the SDK and passing the required secret values ie secretAccessKey, accessKeyId, and region.

Note: Please replace your own AWS secret access key with `your_access_key `, your access key id with `your_accesskey_id` and region with ‘your_aws_region’

const upload = multer({
  storage: multerS3({
    s3: s3,
    bucket: 'bucket-name',
    key: function (req, file, cb) {
      console.log(file);
      cb(null, file.originalname); //use Date.now() for unique file keys
    }
  })
});

Here, We have created a new multer function with storage type as multerS3 storage which will be used to upload our files from local machine or server to s3 bucket. Do not forget to replace ‘bucket-name’ with the actual name of your s3 bucket

//to be used by upload form
app.post('/upload', upload.single('myFile'), function (req, res, next) {
  return res.json("Uploaded!");
});

app.listen(3000, function () {
  console.log('Example app listening on port 3000!');
});

In the end, we have created a new route in our NodeJs express application with endpoint as ‘/upload’ where we will pass our multipart/form-data from the HTML upload form we created earlier in the tutorial at the first step.

In the above route, we are using the multer upload function as a middleware in our route function so once the request is consumed by our route, our middleware will be executed first ie our file will be uploaded to s3 and after that, it will return a response back to our HTML file with text as ‘Uploaded!’

Finally, we are binding our application to listen to incoming Http requests on port 3000.

Guys, even though tourism activities are now happening, avoid heading out unless absolutely necessary and even if you do, make sure you follow all the prohibitory orders.

This is an interesting ad by Patagonia. Patagonia is a designer of outdoor clothing and gear for the silent sports: climbing, surfing, skiing and snowboarding, fly fishing, and trail running. The ad as you may have noticed is very odd at first sight. When one looks at the ad, the world that generally comes to mind is sustainable, unconventional, creative, innovative. 

1. It provides a sustainable model towards the clothing industry by offering a partnership to the consumer and change the world together. 

2. It also uses the AIDA (Attention, Interesting, Desire, Action) model very well. the model used in marketing that describes the steps a customer goes through in the process of purchasing a product. 

a. Firstly, it attracts the attention of the consumer through a surprising statement that contradicts the purpose of ads by suggesting the consumer not to buy the product showcased. 

b. Second, its interest is generated through humor as the viewer is puzzled by the statement and searches for the explanation. It keeps the viewer engaged by what both the company and the consumer will do in this unique partnership or initiative. while doing this it also showcases the benefits of the products they make. 

c. Third, a desire to be the positive change in the world, do the heroic thing, and be a part of something bigger than themselves by being a part of this partnership is invoked in the viewer. 

d. Call for action is given in the ad by offering a partnership to reimagine the world with Patagonia. the viewer can visit their website given in the poster to know about the company, its offerings, and the initiative.

content.text:
SEVERAL PROMINENT technology companies recently predicted that a zettabyte of data will soon be racing about the Internet.

It is no small problem when words fail to capture the world’s immensity. When old concepts fail to keep up with changes, traditions and past experiences become inadequate guides for what to do next.

Managers are working their way out to develop new data-oriented management systems that make sense of the enormous data and use the analytics to generate value and get a competitive advantage.

Organizations are categorized into three levels on the basis of their adoption to data analytics:

  1. Aspirationals – basic analytics users
  2. Experienced – rely on analytics to guide strategy as well as day-to-day activities
  3. Transformed – are strong and sophisticated analytics users.

What is in analytics that produces value and how organizations can reap the benefit out of this?

It is not the tool or people but the organizational factor like being open to change and new ideas; having a unified focus on the customer that is driven by analytics, and using analytics to identify and address strategic threats to the organization which decides how an organization can get a competitive advantage. Also, without strong cultural commitments, the success of an analytics program can be easily shortchanged or derailed. 

Transformed companies tend to have a data-oriented culture as well as competency in two areas: Information management and analytic expertise. Together, a data-oriented culture, information management, and analytic expertise foster what we call competitive analytics.

Three Elements of a Data-Oriented Culture

  1. Analytics is used as a strategic asset;
  2. Management supports analytics throughout the organization;
  3. Insights are widely available to those who need them.

A data-oriented culture is a pattern of behaviors and practices by a group of people(in a department, line of business, or enterprise) who share a belief that having, understanding, and using certain kinds of data play a critical role in the success of their business. 

Foundations of Analytic Competence

Analytic expertise is built from talent, tools, and technology, whereas a solid information management agenda is built from strong data governance,  data management practices, and the capability to deliver the right information to the right people at the right time.

But the big question - Which competency should a manager tackle first?

There is no “typical” sequential evolution of competencies and culture Experienced organizations are taking one of two distinct approaches to analytics.

  1. Developing their information management competency, with attention focused on creating an enterprise-wide information platform to support broad and consistent use of analytics called Collaborative Organizations.
  2. Building their analytics expertise called Specialized Organizations.

Collaborative Organizations Emphasize Information Management

Collaborative organizations are almost three times more likely to use analytics to guide future strategies than Specialized organizations and are shifting to rely on analytics in day-to-day operations as well, at twice the rate of Specialized organizations.

Specialized Organizations Emphasize Analytics Expertise

they are applying advanced modeling techniques to data to create simulations, prototypes, and scenarios to better understand how changes — from internal investments or external forces— will impact processes, revenue growth, and operating costs.

So, which competency you tackle first depends on what kind of company you are, what kind of industry you are in, and what kind of company you want to become.

title: Creating Business Value With Analytics - Summary
feature_content: This article discusses how businesses can create value with analytics.

content.text:
Under pressure to keep costs down, customers may only look at the price and not listen to your sales pitch. Help them understand—and believe in— the superior value of your offerings

“Customer value proposition” has become one of the most widely used terms in business markets in recent years. Yet what constitutes as value addition is still debatable. Most value propositions make claims of savings and beneﬁts to the customer without backing them up.

Some managers view the customer value proposition as a form of spin their marketing departments develop for advertising and promotional copy. This shortsighted view neglects the very real contribution of value propositions to superior business performance.

Once companies become disciplined about understanding customers, they can make smarter choices about where to allocate scarce company resources in developing new offerings.

Suppliers use the term “value proposition” into three types:

  1. All Benefits - list all the beneﬁts they believe that their offering might deliver to target customers. This relative simplicity has a major potential drawback: beneﬁt assertion.
  2. Favorable points of differences – value proposition explicitly recognizes that the customer has an alternative. This can lead to value presumption: assuming that favorable points of difference must be valuable for the customer.
  3. Resonating focus – resonating focus value proposition should be the gold standard. This type of proposition differs from favorable points of difference in two signiﬁcant respects. 
    • More is not better - concentrates on the one or two points of difference that deliver, and whose improvement will continue to deliver, the greatest value to target customers
    • Contain a point of parity

Resonating focus value propositions are very effective, but they’re not easy to craft.

Value word equations enable a supplier to show points of difference and points of contention relative to the next best alternative,  so that customer managers can easily grasp them and ﬁnd them persuasive.

Demonstrate Customer Value in Advance

Value case histories document the cost savings or added value that reference customers have actually received from their use of the supplier’s market offering.

As suppliers gain experience documenting the value provided to customers, they become knowledgeable about how their offerings deliver superior value to customers and even how the value delivered varies across kinds of customers. Because of this extensive and detailed knowledge, they become conﬁdent in predicting the cost savings and added value that prospective customers likely will receive.

Best-practice suppliers recognize that constructing and substantiating resonating focus value propositions is not an onetime undertaking, so they make sure their people know how to identify what the next value propositions ought to be.
